transcripts.transcript: The disengagement between Chinese and Indian troops along the line of actual control in Ladakh has begun. But many are asking that what led to the Chinese decision to withdraw and withdraw so quickly from the areas that they had made massive ingress along the line of actual control since April last year, a broad assessment would tell us that the Chinese are looking to have conveyed to New Delhi. They point that they do not take the assertions by India that the entire territory of Ladakh includes excision and the fact that China is an adversary that India was willing to take on with the Americans. China has conveyed its point, but equally India has also conveyed a point to the Chinese that the Indian military is not the military of 1962 and the Indian leadership is not the leadership of 1962 where we bungled our way into the conflict with the Chinese and where we did not let our military fight. One of the redeeming features of this entire standoff has been the decision of the Modi government to largely leave matters to the military and in fact they did not allow the situation to escalate even by not naming the Chinese as the aggressors, but conveyed that the era of expansionism is over. What is more important is that India dug its heels in and made it known that as far as India was concerned, no part of Indian territory was negotiable. And where the lines have come to be the perceived lines which are called the line of actual control, those lines will be respected by both sides. That was the defining position of India in all the talks that went on with the Chinese to say that unless that principle is respected, there is not going to be a cooling down of pressure between the two sides. Also, the nine rounds of talks and soon to be the 10th round of talks have largely been led by the corps commanders from the Indian side, and a co commander is a left general who is responsible for a large sector where operations can be conducted, and he has troops to the range of 40 to 50,000 soldiers fully equipped and trained for war. China realised that the Indian army is not a pushover. India's military commanders know what they're talking about and Delhi gave them the support that they required. And unlike earlier rounds of many negotiations with the Chinese, which is largely held at the terms of engagement laid down by the Indian Ministry of External Affairs based on the advice of the military and the China Study Group and various others in this case the Ministry of External Affairs did provide, particularly from the months of October, November December, a additional secretary level officer who came in as an observer and giving a sort of guidance to the military commanders. But the military commanders had very clear directions from the higher military authorities in Delhi as to what were India's terms and what they could not concede on. So the Chinese achieved a couple of things. The first is this entire area that we are hearing about, which is in the range of about, um, anything in the range of about 10 kilometres plus minus where there is a controversy that why finger four and finger eight are not being patrolled. Now we need to understand a few specifics. The entire Chinese ingress on the L a over the last 8 to 10 months has been in areas which are in the range of 150 or more kilometres. But this penong so banks, which is constantly being discussed, has contentious areas which are largely fingers 4567 and eight. Now these fingers are spur lines or ridge lines that taper down into the pangs. Lake and India's old position was largely between fingers three and eight Indian troops used to do patrolling and Chinese also did patrolling, and this led to many standoffs, many rounds of jostling but no firing at each other. But the Chinese entry into these areas have come about 423 reasons, one straight after the Cargill conflict or thereabouts, the Chinese took a decision to build their roads from the rear, coming towards the penggung social side to stake further claim and to move their troops quickly in. When they decided to do. They did that by March April last year, and therefore they rapidly moved in their troops pretending to do exercises. On that front, India was taken by surprise. But then India also surprise the Chinese in August by occupying some of the other heights around the Chu area, which is around the Pongs Lake, which for all practical purposes lies here in front of us. And this took the Chinese completely by surprise because those heights, the Kalash Range heights, are places from where India could look down and Indian troops could look down on Chinese position and harass their movements in and out of the stretch between Finger four and Finger eight. Now this stretch has become non pa, controllable by both sides. Perhaps it suits the Chinese because they've made the roads from the rear up to the stretch. They've gone back. But in the event of them wanting to surprise us, they can quickly move their troops in. Secondly, the other aspect that India needs to understand is that India would need to invest a lot more in terms of equipment manning the boundaries because mountains always eat up troops and be constantly on a state of alert towards a possible Chinese surprise. And that surprise could come on the LC or could come further up on the Make me line near Arunachal Pradesh. Because China is now having faced two embarrassing standoffs with India, one at Dole and one around penggung so and further north towards Galan is not going to sit quiet about it would look for another opportunity to surprise us. And the argument that this disengagement is going to be the end of Indochinese hostility is wrong because China does not see India as a friend. What needs to be understand, understood by us that the military and their inputs would be required much more extensively in all future rounds of engagements with the Chinese, as we've seen with the talks, the other area is that what do we do from here? We've managed to get the Chinese to go back and more or less respect the line of actual control that we were demanding. That is around finger eight, the Sja area, and we were largely positioned a dancing tapa post around finger three and in between used to be stretches of patrolling. But now both sides have agreed not to patrol there. The point that India has given away an advantage is a question that will be answered in due course of time because our negotiators and military commanders would perhaps have something more up their sleeve to try and extract another concession from China. Having got them to pull back, though pulling back is probably to China's advantage because their troops, largely conscripts, were complaining and were unable to constantly take the hard tenure along the L AC. So they wanted to go back to the rear. How far back are they gonna go to the rear? At least 50 kilometres for the tanks and all to go back so that in case they decide to make another surprise ingress towards our front lines, 50 kilometres would give us 1.5 to 2 days of notice to deploy our troops to stop them. Some say they may go back up to 500 kilometres away from the L to where they have proper built up military stations and cantonments from where they could launch their reserves if they so desire. But the issue that needs to be understood that the LC standoff has now brought home the fact that you now have with China and Pakistan together a two front threat. Earlier, the understanding was a two front threat would largely involve operations in the plains of Rajasthan and Punjab and a standoff with the Chinese somewhere along the Himalayan frontier. But now the two front threat seems to have married or met up with the Pakistanis, operating very closely with the Chinese and with their support militarily in the areas north of Kashmir and Ladakh, what we call the Po and the Gilgit Baltistan belt up to the Shak Kam Valley, which is with China and which China has been trying to reach via the Desan plains into the Karakoram Pass and marrying up into the Shakka Valley. Why? Because China has made huge investments in that area both for the China Pakistan Economic Corridor and for the multiple dams that it has built there, which collectively is going to provide China all the water and energy plus the static water in the dams to be used up with the sands of the Tala Maan desert north of Ladakh in the sink area and beyond to make silicon wafers. Details of that are available in other sources of the Internet, so the Chinese are going to remain focused on the L a and to engage with the Pakistanis to give us dual challenge for the question for us to is that how much are we going to invest in taking on this dual challenge? Because the dual challenge is going to have massive impact on the Indian defence spending at the same time will constantly keep us in a state of alert. No military in the world wants to be constantly in a warlike situation. They would rather be in a war deterrent situation. So we need to understand that while with Pakistan, we'd established an equation of strategic restraint, which means that we could hit them after an Uri type attack by them by the jihadis and militants or a Pulwama type attack again on India. We could hit them with commandos or air strikes with China. You could not scale up things that quickly. You have to show a certain amount of credible deterrence but restraint because any escalation with China on the Sino Indian boundary, the harsh truth is despite America's assertions and anti China noises. India will have to fight the Chinese alone with the Pakistanis on our back, and it's not going to be a very happy situation. The other aspect is pushed into an embarrassing situation, and one of the reasons why they had made this ingress on the L AC was to ward off the negative propaganda against China for the covid virus spread and to please their sympathisers and their population that they still have the muscle to do as they please and shape the dynamics of Asian politics. China could be pushed into resorting to other measures with the use of non conventional force levels and means. One of them is the newly understood Chinese philosophy of unrestricted warfare, which means get into the economy of your adversary, play up with the sentiments of those who oppose the government of the day and support them through handouts and other benefits, and gradually create considerable impact on the country's cyber systems by the use of cyber and other methodologies to paralyse the systems of an adversary. China has been trying to do this in the United States, and if the enmity with India becomes more pronounced, the possibility of China doing this against India cannot be ruled out. So we need to plan and prepare for that because that is my view that we need to look at, not just the disengagement is done, so let's go back to business as usual. It will never be business as usual with the Chinese again. We just need to prepare for the next set of surprises One way out of that is President Xi Jinping has massive control over the Chinese systems. Prime Minister Modi is as powerful as an Indian prime minister could be in recent memory. So there is a need for the leadership of both countries to go back to the drawing board and look at how we can settle matters over the boundary so that they don't spill over and escalate into a conflict. Now political leaders in India have always found it impossible to address the L AC and the McMahon line boundary question. In all honesty, there is a history to it. From the times of Pandit Nehru, there was an ostrich like attitude in not wanting to address China's claim lines because there was a belief that the lines that had come to be historically, which are contentious. Whether it's the Indian Claim line of Johnson line, which goes beyond the L AC into what the Indian map shows of ladak or the Chinese claim line of the 1959 60 or the lines that have come to be with certain amounts of discussion between the two sides. What is now called the perceived L a. The line of actual control really is a terminology that came into being from 1996 onwards from the time of China's leader, Deng JIA ping, and both sides said, We will respect it, but we'll try and find a solution around it. But 25 years or more is a long enough time for both sides now to find a solution. Unless that is done, be prepared for more surprises. Be prepared for another round of standoffs, and the next round of standoffs may not just end as smoothly as this one has.
